pull.title: Avoid unnecessary copying of non-cheaply-copied types
pull.body:
* Avoid unnecessary copying of non-cheaply-copied types. Use pass by reference to const consistently where appropriate.
* Don't use pass by reference to const for cheaply-copied types (bool, char, etc.).

events.message: Avoid unnecessary copying of non-cheaply-copied types. Use pass by reference to const consistently.
Don't use pass by reference to const for cheaply-copied fundamental types (bool, char, etc.).

events.body: PR title too long. Please keep it short and clear.

What are the non-cheaply-copied types? Have you measured the difference?

Also, this is incomplete, for instance, for type `uint256`:
```cpp
bool bumpFee(uint256 hash);
```
could be
```cpp
bool bumpFee(const uint256& hash);
```
@promag Generally, anything larger than 1 or 2 pointers is better passed by reference.

@promag See @sipa:s answer for the common definition of (non-)cheaply-copied types.

Regarding completeness: I only targeted `const` arguments.

rename.from: Avoid unnecessary copying of non-cheaply-copied types. Use pass by reference to const consistently where appropriate.
rename.to: Avoid unnecessary copying of non-cheaply-copied types

events.body: These kinds of changes scare me, see the bug introduced in CFeeBumper. Some of them are obvious, some of them could subtley introduce bugs (did you look deeply at the CTxMempool changes?).
@TheBlueMatt Good point! I missed the `std::move(â€¦)`. Closing this PR - I'll have to evaluate it deeper and contemplate if the performance reward is worth any potential risk. Thanks for reviewing!

comments.body: To get signature consistency with `GetImmatureWatchOnlyCredit`. See the other changes made to the same file.
This is broken - txidIn is std::move()d two lines down.

It certainly seems misplaced, but it's not actually wrong, as std::move in this case just casts to `const uint256&&`, which won't be moved from (also, uint256 doesn't have a move constructor that destroys the argument).

`const uint256&` will not be moved,  `std::move` is simply a cast,  it will do nothing here.
Ref: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/28595117/why-can-we-use-stdmove-on-a-const-object

```txidIn``` should not be const nor pass-by-reference.
If ```CFeeBumper``` is going to cannibalize ```txidIn``` two lines down it should be copied in the case it was an lvalue. In the case that it was an rvalue, it will not be copied anyway.
```const uint256&``` only causes inefficiencies (due to unnecessary copying) when the caller sends ```txidIn``` as an rvalue

edit: My mistake, the inefficiency I mentioned above only applies when having to reallocate data for each pointer in uint256, which there are none. While using pass by reference will save you 1 copy.
@sipa sorry, broken is a bad word there, I meant "unsafe code", ie we want to be careful of having code like that.
